verses.text: As he looked up, Jesus saw the rich putting their gifts into the temple treasury.

rsbNotes.title: Luke 21:1
rsbNotes.text: 21:1 the offering box. In the court of the women there were thirteen trumpet-shaped collection boxes with inscriptions showing the use to which donations would be put.

verses.text: He also saw a poor widow put in two very small copper coins.
"I tell you the truth," he said, "this poor widow has put in more than all the others.
All these people gave their gifts out of their wealth; but she out of her poverty put in all she had to live on."

rsbNotes.title: Luke 21:2
rsbNotes.text: 21:2 poor. An unusual word (only here in New Testament) meaning “very poor.” Her total livelihood (v. 4) was two copper coins of the lowest value (see text note).

verses.text: Some of his disciples were remarking about how the temple was adorned with beautiful stones and with gifts dedicated to God. But Jesus said,

rsbNotes.title: Luke 21:5
rsbNotes.text: 21:5 noble stones. See note Mark 13:2.

verses.text: "As for what you see here, the time will come when not one stone will be left on another; every one of them will be thrown down."
"Teacher," they asked, "when will these things happen? And what will be the sign that they are about to take place?"

rsbNotes.title: Luke 21:6
rsbNotes.text: 21:6 This was fulfilled during the destruction of Jerusalem in a.d. 70.

verses.text: He replied: "Watch out that you are not deceived. For many will come in my name, claiming, 'I am he,' and, 'The time is near.' Do not follow them.

rsbNotes.title: Luke 21:8
rsbNotes.text: 21:8 I am He. False teachers will claim to be the Christ.

verses.text: When you hear of wars and revolutions, do not be frightened. These things must happen first, but the end will not come right away."
Then he said to them: "Nation will rise against nation, and kingdom against kingdom.
There will be great earthquakes, famines and pestilences in various places, and fearful events and great signs from heaven.

rsbNotes.title: Luke 21:9
rsbNotes.text: 21:9 the end. The end of all things. Some sections of this discourse refer to the destruction of Jerusalem in a.d. 70 and others to Jesus’ coming at the end of the age (Mark 13:4 note).

verses.text: "But before all this, they will lay hands on you and persecute you. They will deliver you to synagogues and prisons, and you will be brought before kings and governors, and all on account of my name.

rsbNotes.title: Luke 21:12
rsbNotes.text: 21:12 synagogues. Synagogues were centers for discipline as well as places of worship.

verses.text: This will result in your being witnesses to them.
But make up your mind not to worry beforehand how you will defend yourselves.
For I will give you words and wisdom that none of your adversaries will be able to resist or contradict.

rsbNotes.title: Luke 21:13
rsbNotes.text: 21:13 Trouble for the church also means opportunity to bear witness.

verses.text: You will be betrayed even by parents, brothers, relatives and friends, and they will put some of you to death.
All men will hate you because of me.
But not a hair of your head will perish.
By standing firm you will gain life.

rsbNotes.title: Luke 21:16–19
rsbNotes.text: 21:16–19 This passage is a strong affirmation of God’s overriding control. For some of His followers there will be a martyr’s death, for others deliverance. Either way, God is bringing His purposes to pass.

verses.text: "When you see Jerusalem being surrounded by armies, you will know that its desolation is near.

rsbNotes.title: Luke 21:20
rsbNotes.text: 21:20 Jerusalem. This section refers to the destruction of the city, not the end time (v. 9 note).

verses.text: Then let those who are in Judea flee to the mountains, let those in the city get out, and let those in the country not enter the city.

rsbNotes.title: Luke 21:21
rsbNotes.text: 21:21 flee to the mountains. People would normally flee to a walled city for shelter from an invading army, but Jerusalem is doomed. People must run away from it, not try to enter it.

verses.text: For this is the time of punishment in fulfillment of all that has been written.

rsbNotes.title: Luke 21:22
rsbNotes.text: 21:22 vengeance. Not meaningless suffering, but the divine penalty.

verses.text: How dreadful it will be in those days for pregnant women and nursing mothers! There will be great distress in the land and wrath against this people.

rsbNotes.title: Luke 21:23
rsbNotes.text: 21:23 Alas. The siege of Jerusalem in a.d. 70 in fact brought extreme suffering.

verses.text: They will fall by the sword and will be taken as prisoners to all the nations. Jerusalem will be trampled on by the Gentiles until the times of the Gentiles are fulfilled.

rsbNotes.title: Luke 21:24
rsbNotes.text:
21:24 the times of the Gentiles. This may mean the time when the Gentiles will have their triumph over Israel, or the time when the gospel is preached to the Gentiles, or both.

fulfilled. A divine purpose will be worked out (cf. Rom. 11:1–32).

verses.text: "There will be signs in the sun, moon and stars. On the earth, nations will be in anguish and perplexity at the roaring and tossing of the sea.
Men will faint from terror, apprehensive of what is coming on the world, for the heavenly bodies will be shaken.

rsbNotes.title: Luke 21:25–26
rsbNotes.text: 21:25, 26 Attention moves to the Second Coming of Christ (v. 9 note). It will be preceded by signs that will puzzle many.

verses.text: At that time they will see the Son of Man coming in a cloud with power and great glory.

rsbNotes.title: Luke 21:27
rsbNotes.text: 21:27 coming. Jesus’ return will be a coming in splendor to reign.

verses.text: When these things begin to take place, stand up and lift up your heads, because your redemption is drawing near."

rsbNotes.title: Luke 21:28
rsbNotes.text: 21:28 redemption. This word means deliverance on payment of a price. Jesus paid the price at Calvary, and He here looks forward to the final fulfillment of what that deliverance means.
